entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
02/03 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-forty-third edition:

Laura:
  • Lektor - From Carinthia with love: a new static CMS created by Armin Ronacher
  • Getting started in Open Source - A list of articles, tutorials and resources
Markus:
  • The Two Hard Things
  • Improve your PostgreSQL workflow with vim and dbext - You got psql in my Vim.
  • Why don’t schools teach debugging? - It’s a fundamental skill, but there are no classes for it.
Gerald:
  • Stay Static Showcase - Inspired by TodoMVC Showcase; Same Sample Site Built w/ Jekyll, Middleman (Yes!), Hugo and others
  • Static Times - We live in static times! Follow along - the latest news (incl. static site spotlights) about Jekyll, Middleman and friends
  • Vienna.html 2nd Meetup - Tu Feb/23rd - Join us @ sektor5. Free. Everyone welcome. Short talks about Building Page Layouts with Susy Grid by Bernhard Benke; Using Markdown (HTML “Shortcodes” in Plain Vanilla Text) with the kramdown Library and Tools by Thomas Leitner and (much) more
  • GitHub Pages now faster and simpler with Jekyll 3.0 - Yay!

entry.title: Viennarb #29 — Summary
entry.content:
Happy new year! For our twenty-ninth vienna.rb we had a relatively laid back edition. Great time to catch up after the winter break!

For starters, some announcements:

  • The Rails Girls Summer of Code Call for Projects is open! Submit your open source project and help support newcomers get into open source software development. Find out more http://railsgirlssummerofcode.org/guide/projects/
  • We’d love to get feedback from you! Drop us a line at hello@vienna-rb.at
  • Our Slack channel is live! Sign up here.

We kicked off with a proposal from Max on dedicating some time for members of the meetup to come up and give us a quick look into their daily work toolchain. A ‘How We Work’, if you will.

Our Talks

For our main talk, Aaron showed us ‘Crystal For Rubyists’. The main issue with Ruby being discussed nowadays is that of concurrency. While looking at alternatives, such as Go, Elixir, and the IO language, Aaron came upon the Crystal language.

Some plus points about Crystal:

  • It’s got a Ruby-like syntax. So much so, that when showing us some code, Aaron had initially led us to believe that we were looking at Ruby, when we were in fact looking at Crystal. Devious!
  • It’s statically typed.
  • It has a Go-like concurrency.
  • You can generate new projects with the Crystal command line interface.
  • You can compile and run your code, but also do so separately, as you would with C.

Be sure to check out the Awesome page for Crystal!

Discussion Round

Our discussion round was broken into smaller groups, but here’s some tips that came up:

  • Prezto: Config framework for zsh
  • Mensch: Menlo-like font

That, along with some friendly catching up and meeting new folks, wrapped up our meetup!

Looking forward to the next one!

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
01/27 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-forty-third edition:

Laura:
  • TrumpScript - It’s not Ruby but it’s still too great not to share.
  • Lotus is now Hanami - Lotus has recently been renamed; read all about it in this blog post.
Ramón:
  • Nativefier - Run web apps as if they were native! Runs on Electron.
  • RubyMotion: MotionKit - Really helpful DSL for setting up view layouts. No need for Interface Builder files!
  • Influencing Web Layouts with Print Layouts - I found this an interesting read on using more magazine-styled layouts.
Markus:
  • On Ergonomics - Why an ergonomic working place is important (unless you like constant pain)
  • Conceptual Debt is Worse than Technical Debt - Yes, there’s something even worse than technical debt out there.
  • How to trick a neural network into thinking a panda is a vulture - Neural networks can do amazing things, but they can be tricked into seeing things that aren’t quite what they seem.
Max:
  • The Bike Shed 48: “Is Everyone Trying Their Best?” - Software is broken - Derek and Sean on why it’s not fun to be one of the developers who just don’t care.
  • Switching from rbenv to postmodern’s ruby-install and chruby - Remind the unix philosophy and ditch rbenv (or rvm) for something more lightweight.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
01/20 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-forty-second edition:

Laura:
  • What is the best programming language for me? - a small and fun questionnaire to find out which programming language is the right one for you
  • Awesome machine learning - A curated list of great machine learning frameworks, libraries, etc.. in different languages. Ruby is in there, too!
  • Contempt Culture - A short article worth reading.
Ramón:
  • 101 Ruby Code Factoids - Super neat bite-sized tips and tricks. This counts as 101 picks!
Markus:
  • Programming advice from John Carmack - John Carmack provides adivce and thoughts for beginning programmers. Actually, his advice is pretty good for anyone wanting to learn something new related to programming.
  • Ruby’s “unless X” is processed differently than “if !X”!
  • Postgres 9.5 - the Feature Rundown - PostgreSQL 9.5 was released almost two weeks ago, and Craig Kerstiens provides a great rundown of all the new features. Personally, I’m really hyped about having Upsert.
Lauris:
  • 7 ways to decompose fat activerecord models - nice intro into object oriented rails programming
  • anatomy of a rails service object - my favourite article on service objects
  • activemodel form objects - basic idea of form objects

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
01/13 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-forty-first edition:

Laura:
  • Ruby Rogues 241 - The latest Ruby Rogues episode is about What Makes a Great Developer, and is absolutely worth listening to.
  • How to honor Aaron Swartz - It’s been 2 years since Swartz' suicide, and Ben Wikler wrote a post about how to make sure that the cause he fought and died for didn’t die with him. It’s a really sad but interesting read that makes you reconsider what you do every day, and how to improve your life to make a difference in the world.
Ramón:
  • (OS X) Self Control - Block your access to websites that distract you
  • CSS Diner - Fun way to learn CSS selectors!
  • Pairing With Junior Developers
Markus:
  • How To Safely Store A Password - Spoiler: use bcrypt. Read on for details.
  • Postgres 9.5 - the Feature Rundown - 9.5 was released last week, and here’s what’s new.
  • IPv6 celebrates its 20th birthday by reaching 10 percent deployment - 10% might not sound impressive, until you realize what was involved in getting there.
Aaron:
  • Locomotive CMS hits 3.0 - Locomotive CMS is my favorite CMS (besides Comfortable Mexican Sofa) and it just hit a long awaited 3.0 this week.
  • Comfortable Mexican Sofa - Since I mentioned it above, I’ve gotta share this great, plug-in Rails Engine CMS.
  • Trailblazer - Trailblazer is a Rails and other system friendly architecture. It’s maybe what Rails would look like if software design was up higher on its list of goals. I’m reading the book and I’m super into it. I’ve started converting some projects over, and using the concepts in other projects.
Max:
  • Defensive BASH Programming - Will make you go refactor all your .sh scripts…
  • Building a Slackbot with Ruby and Sinatra - Build a tiny Slackbot in 5 minutes.
  • Changelog #189: JSON API with Yehuda Katz - Listen to Yehuda share some thoughts on extracting standards and enabling people.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
01/06 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-fortieth edition:

Laura:
  • The Rubyist’s guide to environment variables - How environment variables really work
  • Bath Ruby - The last batch of Bath Ruby tickets is on sale. Get them while they’re hot! (Also, they might be sold out soon)
  • lesscode - The main ideas behind the less code movement
Markus:
  • Craig Kerstiens' Top 10 Postgres Features and Tips for 2016
  • Visualizing Algorithms - Not just visualized, but also a discussion of different ways to visualize an algorithm.
  • The Website Obesity Crisis - On the phenomenon of mostly-text websites that keep growing in size each year.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
12/30 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-thirty-ninth edition:

Laura:
  • How to fix a bug in an Open Source Project - this article isn’t so much about making your first pull request (though it lists a couple of important tips) but rather, about the process of fixing bugs for a codebase you’re unfamiliar with.
  • Ruby 2.3.0 - Ruby 2.3.0 was released on Christmas day.
  • RailsConf CFP - The RailsConf CFP is still open until January 15th.
Markus:
  • Fallout 4 Service Discovery and Relay - You might not care about Fallout 4, but Kyle Kelley’s post on how he figured out how the companion iOS/Android app finds and communicates with the game is a very interesting read in any case.
  • 25,000+ Req/s for Rack JSON API with MRuby - mruby doesn’t get nearly as much coverage as Ruby does, but as Luca Guidi shows, mruby doesn’t have to hide in the shadow of its older sibling, especially when it comes to performance.
  • The 100:10:1 method: my approach to open source - @fogus explains his decision making process for what to release as open source.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
12/23 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-thirty-eighth edition:

Laura:
  • Junior developer - What does it mean? A look at the responsibilities, rather than the skillset, of a junior developer
  • Shrine - There’s a new file uploader in town! Meet Shrine.
  • 32C3 - Chaos Communication Congress is starting this weekend. Some of the Viennese Rubyists will be there – come say hello! Or if you can’t attend, here is a link to the recordings and live stream.
Markus:
  • The Inescapable Pragmatism of Procedures - Avdi Grimm on the strength and weaknesses of a functional vs. a procedural approach to problems.
  • The Jacob’s Ladder of coding - “Anecdotes and questions about climbing up and down the ladder of abstraction” (plus some interesting tidbits about old computer hardware).
  • Ignorance Beats Empathy - Mike Monteiro on how to achieve better empathy towards users in design.
Ramón:
  • Codecademy’s AngularJS course - I’m about halfway through and have found this helpful and a lot of fun!
  • Christmas Tree Formatter for Rspec - Run your tests festively!
  • RubyMotion motion-support gem - Like ActiveSupport, but for RubyMotion!

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
12/16 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-thirty-seventh edition:

Laura:
  • Italy on Rails - A code-journey through Italy; you can apply by email to participate for two weeks in April/May.
  • Advent of Code - Small and self-contained programming puzzled to count your way to Christmas!
  • Coursera - Coursera now has a Ruby On Rails Specialization from Johns Hopkins University.
Markus:
  • The Adventures of printf: A Short Story - Fred Herbet takes us on a journey of a little guy named printf, who’s in search of mentoring as a programmer — and the greater meaning of why we code.
  • When to not be a software craftsman - Programming is often talked about as either art or a craft. But Chad Fowler argues that sometimes, it’s neither — and that’s ok.
  • I Dreamed of a Perfect Database - Paul Ford thinks about databases, and how we order information can reshape our world.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
12/09 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-thirty-sixth edition:

Laura:
  • The life-changing magic of tidying up - .. with web components
  • So you want to learn how to code - Isis Anchalee, the person behind the #ILookLikeAnEngineer hashtag, put together a great article with a huge list of resources for people looking to learn how to code, from web development to algorithms.
Markus:
  • To the Moon: Parallels Between Space Missions and Developing Software - Russ Olsen (of Eloquent Ruby and Design Patterns in Ruby fame) presented the keynote at GOTO Berlin 2015. InfoQ interviewed him about it.
  • 7 common database design errors - Demonstrated using real-life examples.
  • The TTY demystified - Did you know that the fancy terminal you’re using for your command line can trace its lineage back to a stock ticker device first released in 1869? And it’s still emulating a video terminal from the 1970s?

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
12/02 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-thirty-fifth edition:

Laura:
  • Nanoc - Yet Another Static Site Generator written in Ruby. Because we can!
  • What Open Source project should I contribute to? - A good, solid post to help you through making your first contribution, complete with a list of resources
  • Flexbox Froggy - If you’ve been hiding under a rock (or a lilypad) this week, you probably haven’t seen flexbox froggy: THE game to help you learn CSS flexbox!
Markus:
  • John Carmack’s Deep Thoughts: Ideas, Work, and Emotion - John Carmack has done some amzing things over the years. In a talk at facebook, he laid out how he does it.
  • Pushing to the Git Working Copy on a Web Server - Sometimes, you’d just like to push to a Git repo, and have your changes magically appear in the server’s working directory. This shows you how to do that.
  • PostgreSQL Locking Revealed - Postgres can handle a lot of concurrent reads and writes, but sometimes you’ll run into deadlocks. This guide shows you what operation requires what kind of lock, and how compatible they are among each other.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
11/25 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-thirty-fourth edition:

Laura:
  • gitnonymous - Contribute pseudonymously to Git repositories over Tor
  • Effective TDD with Ruby: vim setup - Another instalment of Luca Guidi’s series about TDD – this time with tips on building your own vim setup
  • Kumquat - Render RMarkdown files inside Rails
Floor:
  • React on Rails - React on Rails integrates Facebook’s React front-end framework with Rails. And it’s interesting stuff.
  • emoji support with MySQL & Rails - If you’re a MySQL user with a charset of utf8, you’ve probably noticed your database isn’t as excited about native emoji as your users are. There’s a one-liner to change that though.
  • My life right now - We will meet again.
Markus:
  • Brick laying and bug reports - Thomas Cannon explains how to improve your bug fixing process.
  • There is No Now - We humans might have a concept of “now”, but there is no such thing when it comes to distributed systems.
  • Do You Know What a Good Environment Looks Like, Though?

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
11/18 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-thirty-third edition:

Laura:
  • Understanding self in Ruby - A nice little Ruby self cheat sheet ;)
  • Why is it so hard to find a Front-End developer - I couldn’t agree more: “Front end development, like any specialized trade or spectator sport, is a lot harder than it looks.”
  • Understanding branches in Git - From a series about understanding Git on the thoughtram blog.
Floor:
  • An inside look with Laura Frank - Laura shares on the Codeship blog why she feels a responsibility to speak about tech, why she’s a huge advocate for Docker, and why technologists have an obligation to society.
  • new to the team - The Ruby Rogues discuss onboarding new team members.
  • DevFest 2015 - No plans for this weekend yet? Good. You can still register for the free and fun DevFest, with a remarkably interesting line-up this year.
Markus:
  • What can you put in a refrigerator? - Seems like an easy question, doesn’t it?
  • Suggesting a corrected column name/spelling in the event of a column misspelling - When you mistype a column name in psql, PostgreSQL 9.6 will be able to suggest the correct name for you.
  • Why is Swift’s String API So Hard? - You might think of strings in programming languages as a fairly simple thing, but they really aren’t. Mike Ash describes why the Swift String API is the way it is, which can also teach you a lot about how other languages approach the same topic.
Benjamin
  • Ruby 3 will be 3 times faster - Matz' goal with Ruby 3 is to be 3 times faster than Ruby 2, and the way to reach that goal is corporate sponsorship, says Appfolio and hires/sponsors a full-time engineer to work with the Ruby core team on the performance of Ruby.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
11/10 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-thirty-second edition:

Laura:
  • Understanding the Bootstrap 4 Grid System - If you do web development, chances are you’ve come across Bootstrap. This tutorial takes a look at the grid system in the upcoming version!
  • Bingo board - Yet another awesome project by Mu-An: play bingo by sending in pull requests!
  • github-todos - A Git hook to convert your TODOs into GitHub issues.
Floor:
  • Contribute - Tips for contributing Open Source Projects for beginners, from a beginner.
  • Pull Request Day - One million pull requests in one day. Take the pledge and join International Pull Request Day, February 27th.
  • kondo - inspired by last week of throwing out all the things I’ve adopted the religion of tidying up. Maybe one can also ‘kondo’ their code base.
Markus:
  • Locked doors, headaches, and intellectual need - On problem-solution ordering issues, functional programming, and teaching new concepts.
  • The One-Second War - Everyone knows about leap days, but did you know we also have leap seconds? And that they can cause a lot of havoc?
  • Graph Algorithms in Ruby - Every once in a while, you have to deal with a graph, especially if you touch something related to social networks. This article introduces you to the basic algorithms for dealing with graphs, and their implementation in Ruby.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
11/03 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-thirty-first edition:

Laura:
  • Rails Rumble 2015 - Registration for the Rails Rumble 2015 opened a couple of days ago. Sign up now!
  • How to solve coding anti-patterns for Ruby rookies - A look at the typical patterns that can be found in beginners' code
  • Codepoems - An experimental IDE for Processing
Floor:
  • CSSgram - A library for editing your images with Instagram-like filters directly in CSS. Interesting? Yes. Useful? Maybe.
  • GitHub on-demand training - Start learning and teaching Git and GitHub today with their self-paced training module.
  • There are RubyIssues. Again. - Contribute to this month’s curated open source construction areas in Ruby.
  • The Pretentious Gem - Very much not recommended but still funny: write your code first and then generate tests later.
Markus:
  • Your App Is Good And You Should Feel Good - Design process, emotions, criticism, and psychology. And how all of that fits together.
  • “Why should I care about customer support?” - Caring about your users as a developer means caring about customer support.
  • The Dynamic Def - What happens when you define a method inside another method in Ruby? Jamis Buck has the answer, and a surprisingly useful use case.
Gerald:
  • Jekyll 3.0 Release - What’s News - Congrats to Parker Moore and team; Jekyll 3.0 - static site builder - now includes a new Liquid template profiler, unified posts and collections, hooks and much more
  • Video - Jekyll 3.0 Talk, Q&A and Live Release by Parker Moore - YouTube video (20 mins) of last week’s Jekyll 3.0 talk by Parker Moore in San Francisco, California
  • Jekyll 3 Assets - Congrats to Jordon Bedwell for updating the asset pipeline for use with the latest and greatest Jekyll version
  • Vienna.html - Vienna Static Site User Group; 1st Meetup on Tue Nov/24th @ sektor5 (Siebenbrunnengasse 44, Wien 5) - Join Us - Free - No Database Required ;-)

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
10/28 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-thirtieth edition:

Laura:
  • Join the RailsBridge fundraising team - RailsBridge are looking for members to join their team. Apply by November 15th!
  • Effective TDD with Ruby: Time and Flow - Lotus creator Luca Guidi is putting together an article series about TDD. First up is time management!
Floor:
  • PubNub - Building a realtime quiz with Ruby on Rails, ReactJS & PubNub.
  • EuRuKo 2015 Review - As I couldn’t make it to EuRuKo all I have to go on is your stories, and this great summary.
  • Rails 5 - An elaborate summary of what’s new in Rails 5.
Markus:
  • Dark corners of Unicode - A meditation on the hidden depths of Unicode.
  • Writing an OS in Rust - Philipp Oppermann is building an OS in Rust, and you can follow along on his blog.
  • Speed up with Materialized Views on PostgreSQL and Rails - How you can use PostgreSQL’s materialized views to speed up your app without having to maintain extra tables.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
10/21 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-twenty-ninth edition:

Laura:
  • Rails Remote Conf - Because remote confs are a thing now.
  • Esoteric programming languages - A fun little list
Floor:
  • hiring diversely - The RubyRogues discuss hiring diversely with Sarah Mei.
  • Low Line - There is an alternative to New York’s famous High Line, the in-development Low Line. The underground park is found on the lower east side of Manhattan. And it just looks crazy beautiful.
Markus:
  • Debugging a Memory Leak on Heroku - Richard Schneems shows how to debug memory leaks in your Rails app. Obviously, this also works for Rails apps not hosted on Heroku ;)
  • Storing Data with Redis - Mike Perham on the bad habit of stuffing all your data into one Redis database.
  • Building Learning into our Process with Prototypes - Kyle Fiedler on the importance of prototypes, especially when they fail.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
10/14 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-twenty-eighth edition:

Laura:
  • Octohat - Hang your non-code contributions on your hat rack
  • Photon - Build Electron apps using simple HTML and CSS
  • Using webfonts in 2015 - A pretty good write-up
Floor:
  • Simple Writer - Pretty sure Laura shared this already at one point in time BUT this XKCD’s little app highlights difficult words in your copy. Running your beginners guide through this service is… enlightening.
  • Codecademy Summer of Code - Because interesting: Codecademy sat down with their Summer of Code Challenge winner, Ethan Chiu.
  • Rails Girls Summer of Code wrap-up - very much enjoying the wrap-up posts on the Rails Girls Summer of Code blog.
Markus:
  • Ruby Performance, a Visual Guide - Everyone loves fast code, and this handy post details what tools Ruby offers for each part of your apps stack.
  • Runnable Documentation: Code for Humans - GitHub tries to optimize for as little documentation as possible, and packing as much into the code as they can get away with.
  • In PostgreSQL, as in life, don’t wait too long to commit - It’s an easy thing to overlook, but keep your transactions as short as possible.
Phillipp:
  • maily_herald - Self-hosted Mailchimp alternative. Good alternative after the EUGH decision on Safe Harbour.
  • Conversions @ Google - Luke Wroblewski (Part 1) - Not super fresh, but you see a lot what he talks about in your daily life (and you won’t like it, after you watched the videos)

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
10/07 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-twenty-seventh edition:

Laura:
  • GitHub as a workflow - An interesting look at agile pull requests.
  • How to learn a new programming language - .. while maintaining your day job and still being there for your family
  • The End and a Beginning - Rails Girls Summer of Code 2015 is over. A look at all the awesome people who made it happen.
Aaron:
  • Faraday Gem - Faraday is an HTTP libarary wrapper and middleware suite that makes it easy to build clients to external services. I have been using it a lot lately and I am really liking it.
  • Virtus Gem - Virtus gives you a way to create application domain objects that support some cool stuff like type coersion. It is a great partner with Faraday if your work requires a lot of interfacing with outside services.
Floor:
  • Brian Griffin in pure CSS - Because amazing.
  • arrrrcamp hug - Because nostalgic.
  • ROSSConf recap - Because I had a minute.
Markus:
  • What every programmer absolutely, positively needs to know about encodings and character sets to work with text - Every developer has to deal with text. Knowing what encodings are exactly and how they work will save you a lot of pain and headaches.
  • 9 tips for better database design - Thinking about your data model beforehand will save you time, stress, and tears later down the line, and these tips will help you make better decisions.
  • Storing Data with Redis - You wouldn’t stuff all your data into one single table. Why are you doing it when you’re using Redis, then, asks Mike Perham.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
09/30 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-twenty-sixth edition:

Laura:
  • The real benefits of engaging in Open Source - We’ve said this before, and we’ll say it again..
  • Hacktoberfest - Yes - it’s a thing.
Floor:
  • jobless - DSL written in Ruby for generating CVs. It generates HTML files, which can be easily converted to PDF format.
Markus:
  • How Security Flaws Work: The Buffer Overflow - If you ever wanted to know how Buffer Overflows actually work, this is an in-depth and detailed explanation.
  • Your Single AWS Account is a Serious Risk - If you use AWS, you should make sure you’re not running everything with your ‘root’ account.
  • Be Coachable
